rss.itunes:subtitle: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most ext
rss.itunes:author: TED
rss.itunes:summary: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage.
rss.title: TEDTalks : Simon Sinek: How great leaders inspire action - Simon Sinek (2009)
rss.itunes:author: Simon Sinek
rss.description: Simon Sinek has a simple but powerful model for inspirational leadership all starting with a golden circle and the question "Why?" His examples include Apple, Martin Luther King, and the Wright brothers -- and as a counterpoint Tivo, which (until a recent court victory that tripled its stock price) appeared to be struggling.
rss.itunes:subtitle: Simon Sinek: How great leaders inspire action
rss.itunes:summary: Simon Sinek has a simple but powerful model for inspirational leadership all starting with a golden circle and the question "Why?" His examples include Apple, Martin Luther King, and the Wright brothers -- and as a counterpoint Tivo, which (until a recent court victory that tripled its stock price) appeared to be struggling.

item.title: TEDTalks : Stephen Wolfram: Computing a theory of everything - Stephen Wolfram (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stephen Wolfram
item.description: Stephen Wolfram, creator of Mathematica, talks about his quest to make all knowledge computational -- able to be searched, processed and manipulated. His new search engine, Wolfram Alpha, has no lesser goal than to model and explain the physics underlying the universe.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stephen Wolfram: Computing a theory of everything
item.itunes:summary: Stephen Wolfram, creator of Mathematica, talks about his quest to make all knowledge computational -- able to be searched, processed and manipulated. His new search engine, Wolfram Alpha, has no lesser goal than to model and explain the physics underlying the universe.

item.title: TEDTalks : Omar Ahmad: Political change with pen and paper - Omar Ahmad (2010)
item.itunes:author: Omar Ahmad
item.description: Politicians are strange creatures, says politician Omar Ahmad. And the best way to engage them on your pet issue is a monthly handwritten letter. Ahmad shows why old-fashioned correspondence is more effective than email, phone or even writing a check -- and shares the four simple steps to writing a letter that works.
item.itunes:subtitle: Omar Ahmad: Political change with pen and paper
item.itunes:summary: Politicians are strange creatures, says politician Omar Ahmad. And the best way to engage them on your pet issue is a monthly handwritten letter. Ahmad shows why old-fashioned correspondence is more effective than email, phone or even writing a check -- and shares the four simple steps to writing a letter that works.

item.title: TEDTalks : Tom Wujec: Build a tower, build a team - Tom Wujec (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tom Wujec
item.description: Tom Wujec presents some surprisingly deep research into the "marshmallow problem" -- a simple team-building exercise that involves dry spaghetti, one yard of tape and a marshmallow. Who can build the tallest tower with these ingredients? And why does a surprising group always beat the average?
item.itunes:subtitle: Tom Wujec: Build a tower, build a team
item.itunes:summary: Tom Wujec presents some surprisingly deep research into the "marshmallow problem" -- a simple team-building exercise that involves dry spaghetti, one yard of tape and a marshmallow. Who can build the tallest tower with these ingredients? And why does a surprising group always beat the average?

item.title: TEDTalks : Frederick Balagadde: Bio-lab on a microchip - Frederick Balagadde (2010)
item.itunes:author: Frederick Balagadde
item.description: Drugs alone can't stop disease in sub-Saharan Africa: We need diagnostic tools to match. TED Senior Fellow Frederick Balagadde shows how we can multiply the power and availability of an unwieldy, expensive diagnostic lab -- by miniaturizing it to the size of a chip.
item.itunes:subtitle: Frederick Balagadde: Bio-lab on a microchip

item.title: TEDTalks : James Randi's fiery takedown of psychic fraud - James Randi (2007)
item.itunes:author: James Randi
item.description: Legendary skeptic James Randi takes a fatal dose of homeopathic sleeping pills onstage, kicking off a searing 18-minute indictment of irrational beliefs. He throws out a challenge to the world's psychics: Prove what you do is real, and I'll give you a million dollars. (No takers yet.)
item.itunes:subtitle: James Randi's fiery takedown of psychic fraud

He throws out a challenge to the world's psychics: Prove what you do is real, and I'll give you a million dollars. (No takers yet.)

item.title: TEDTalks : Edith Widder: Glowing life in an underwater world - Edith Widder (2010)
item.itunes:author: Edith Widder
item.description: Some 80 to 90 percent of undersea creatures make light -- and we know very little about how or why. Bioluminescence expert Edith Widder explores this glowing, sparkling, luminous world, sharing glorious images and insight into the unseen depths (and brights) of the ocean.
item.itunes:subtitle: Edith Widder: Glowing life in an underwater world
item.itunes:summary: Some 80 to 90 percent of undersea creatures make light -- and we know very little about how or why. Bioluminescence expert Edith Widder explores this glowing, sparkling, luminous world, sharing glorious images and insight into the unseen depths (and brights) of the ocean.

item.title: TEDTalks : Thelma Golden: How art gives shape to cultural change - Thelma Golden (2009)
item.itunes:author: Thelma Golden
item.description: Thelma Golden, curator at the Studio Museum in Harlem, talks through three recent shows that explore how art examines and redefines culture. The "post-black" artists she works with are using their art to provoke a new dialogue about race and culture -- and about the meaning of art itself.
item.itunes:subtitle: Thelma Golden: How art gives shape to cultural change
item.itunes:summary: Thelma Golden, curator at the Studio Museum in Harlem, talks through three recent shows that explore how art examines and redefines culture. The "post-black" artists she works with are using their art to provoke a new dialogue about race and culture -- and about the meaning of art itself.

item.title: TEDTalks : Mike deGruy: Hooked by an octopus - Mike deGruy (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mike deGruy
item.description: Underwater filmmaker Mike deGruy has spent decades looking intimately at the ocean. A consummate storyteller, he takes the stage at Mission Blue to share his awe and excitement -- and his fears -- about the blue heart of our planet.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mike deGruy: Hooked by an octopus
item.itunes:summary: Underwater filmmaker Mike deGruy has spent decades looking intimately at the ocean. A consummate storyteller, he takes the stage at Mission Blue to share his awe and excitement -- and his fears -- about the blue heart of our planet.

item.title: TEDTalks : Catherine Mohr builds green - Catherine Mohr (2010)
item.itunes:author: Catherine Mohr
item.description: In a short, funny, data-packed talk at TED U, Catherine Mohr walks through all the geeky decisions she made when building a green new house -- looking at real energy numbers, not hype. What choices matter most? Not the ones you think.
item.itunes:subtitle: Catherine Mohr builds green
item.itunes:summary: In a short, funny, data-packed talk at TED U, Catherine Mohr walks through all the geeky decisions she made when building a green new house -- looking at real energy numbers, not hype. What choices matter most? Not the ones you think.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jonathan Klein: Photos that changed the world - Jonathan Klein (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jonathan Klein
item.description: Photographs do more than document history -- they make it. At TED University, Jonathan Klein of Getty Images shows some of the most iconic, and talks about what happens when a generation sees an image so powerful it can't look away -- or back.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jonathan Klein: Photos that changed the world

item.title: TEDTalks : Michael Specter: The danger of science denial - Michael Specter (2010)
item.itunes:author: Michael Specter
item.description: Vaccine-autism claims, "Frankenfood" bans, the herbal cure craze: All point to the public's growing fear (and, often, outright denial) of science and reason, says Michael Specter. He warns the trend spells disaster for human progress.
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael Specter: The danger of science denial
item.itunes:summary: Vaccine-autism claims, "Frankenfood" bans, the herbal cure craze: All point to the public's growing fear (and, often, outright denial) of science and reason, says Michael Specter. He warns the trend spells disaster for human progress.

item.title: TEDTalks : Natalie Merchant sings old poems to life - Natalie Merchant (2010)
item.itunes:author: Natalie Merchant
item.description: Natalie Merchant sings from her new album, Leave Your Sleep. Lyrics from near-forgotten 19th-century poetry pair with her unmistakable voice for a performance that brought the TED audience to its feet.
item.itunes:subtitle: Natalie Merchant sings old poems to life
item.itunes:summary: Natalie Merchant sings from her new album, Leave Your Sleep. Lyrics from near-forgotten 19th-century poetry pair with her unmistakable voice for a performance that brought the TED audience to its feet.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jonathan Drori: Every pollen grain has a story - Jonathan Drori (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jonathan Drori
item.description: Pollen goes unnoticed by most of us, except when hay fever strikes. But microscopes reveal it comes in stunning colors and shapes -- and travels remarkably well. Jonathan Drori gives an up-close glimpse of these fascinating flecks of plant courtship.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jonathan Drori: Every pollen grain has a story
item.itunes:summary: Pollen goes unnoticed by most of us, except when hay fever strikes. But microscopes reveal it comes in stunning colors and shapes -- and travels remarkably well. Jonathan Drori gives an up-close glimpse of these fascinating flecks of plant courtship.

item.title: TEDTalks : Dean Kamen: The emotion behind invention - Dean Kamen (2009)
item.itunes:author: Dean Kamen
item.description: Soldiers who've lost limbs in service face a daily struggle unimaginable to most of us. At TEDMED, Dean Kamen talks about the profound people and stories that motivated his work to give parts of their lives back with his design for a remarkable prosthetic arm.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dean Kamen: The emotion behind invention
item.itunes:summary: Soldiers who've lost limbs in service face a daily struggle unimaginable to most of us. At TEDMED, Dean Kamen talks about the profound people and stories that motivated his work to give parts of their lives back with his design for a remarkable prosthetic arm.

item.title: TEDTalks : Elizabeth Pisani: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational - Elizabeth Pisani (2010)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Pisani
item.description: Armed with bracing logic, wit and her "public-health nerd" glasses, Elizabeth Pisani reveals the myriad of inconsistencies in today's political systems that prevent our dollars from effectively fighting the spread of HIV. Her research with at-risk populations -- from junkies in prison to sex workers on the street in Cambodia -- demonstrates the sometimes counter-intuitive measures that could stall the spread of this devastating disease.
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Pisani: Sex, drugs and HIV -- let's get rational

item.title: TEDTalks : Adora Svitak: What adults can learn from kids - Adora Svitak (2010)
item.itunes:author: Adora Svitak
item.description: Child prodigy Adora Svitak says the world needs "childish" thinking: bold ideas, wild creativity and especially optimism. Kids' big dreams deserve high expectations, she says, starting with grownups' willingness to learn from children as much as to teach.
item.itunes:subtitle: Adora Svitak: What adults can learn from kids
item.itunes:summary: Child prodigy Adora Svitak says the world needs "childish" thinking: bold ideas, wild creativity and especially optimism. Kids' big dreams deserve high expectations, she says, starting with grownups' willingness to learn from children as much as to teach.

item.title: TEDTalks : Derek Sivers: How to start a movement - Derek Sivers (2010)
item.itunes:author: Derek Sivers
item.description: With help from some surprising footage, Derek Sivers explains how movements really get started. (Hint: it takes two.)
item.itunes:subtitle: Derek Sivers: How to start a movement
item.itunes:summary: With help from some surprising footage, Derek Sivers explains how movements really get started. (Hint: it takes two.)

item.title: TEDTalks : Kirk Citron: And now, the real news - Kirk Citron (2010)
item.itunes:author: Kirk Citron
item.description: How many of today's headlines will matter in 100 years? 1000? Kirk Citron's "Long News" project collects stories that not only matter today, but will resonate for decades -- even centuries -- to come. At TED2010, he highlights recent headlines with the potential to shape our future.

item.title: TEDTalks : Shukla Bose: Teaching one child at a time - Shukla Bose (2009)
item.itunes:author: Shukla Bose
item.description: Educating the poor is more than just a numbers game, says Shukla Bose. She tells the story of her groundbreaking Parikrma Humanity Foundation, which brings hope to India's slums by looking past the daunting statistics and focusing on treating each child as an individual.

item.title: TEDTalks : Kevin Bales: How to combat modern slavery - Kevin Bales (2010)
item.itunes:author: Kevin Bales
item.description: In this moving yet pragmatic talk, Kevin Bales explains the business of modern slavery, a multibillion-dollar economy that underpins some of the worst industries on earth. He shares stats and personal stories from his on-the-ground research -- and names the price of freeing every slave on earth right now.

item.title: TEDTalks : Robert Gupta: Music is medicine, music is sanity - Robert Gupta (2010)
item.itunes:author: Robert Gupta
item.description: Robert Gupta, violinist with the LA Philharmonic, talks about a violin lesson he once gave to a brilliant, schizophrenic musician -- and what he learned. Called back onstage later, Gupta plays his own transcription of the prelude from Bach's Cello Suite No. 1.

item.title: TEDTalks : Alan Siegel: Let's simplify legal jargon! - Alan Siegel (2010)
item.itunes:author: Alan Siegel
item.description: Tax forms, credit agreements, healthcare legislation: They're crammed with gobbledygook, says Alan Siegel, and incomprehensibly long. He calls for a simple, sensible redesign -- and plain English -- to make legal paperwork intelligible to the rest of us.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alan Siegel: Let's simplify legal jargon!

item.title: TEDTalks : Juliana Machado Ferreira: The fight to end rare-animal trafficking in Brazil - Juliana Machado Ferreira (2010)
item.itunes:author: Juliana Machado Ferreira
item.description: Biologist Juliana Machado Ferreira, a TED Senior Fellow, talks about her work helping to save birds and other animals stolen from the wild in Brazil. Once these animals are seized from smugglers, she asks, then what?
item.itunes:subtitle: Juliana Machado Ferreira: The fight to end rare-animal trafficking in Brazil
item.itunes:summary: Biologist Juliana Machado Ferreira, a TED Senior Fellow, talks about her work helping to save birds and other animals stolen from the wild in Brazil. Once these animals are seized from smugglers, she asks, then what?

item.title: TEDTalks : Sam Harris: Science can answer moral questions - Sam Harris (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sam Harris
item.description: Questions of good and evil, right and wrong are commonly thought unanswerable by science. But Sam Harris argues that science can -- and should -- be an authority on moral issues, shaping human values and setting out what constitutes a good life.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sam Harris: Science can answer moral questions

item.title: TEDTalks : Jane McGonigal: Gaming can make a better world - Jane McGonigal (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jane McGonigal
item.description: Games like World of Warcraft give players the means to save worlds, and incentive to learn the habits of heroes. What if we could harness this gamer power to solve real-world problems? Jane McGonigal says we can, and explains how.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jane McGonigal: Gaming can make a better world
item.itunes:summary: Games like World of Warcraft give players the means to save worlds, and incentive to learn the habits of heroes. What if we could harness this gamer power to solve real-world problems? Jane McGonigal says we can, and explains how.

item.title: TEDTalks : Eric Dishman: Take health care off the mainframe - Eric Dishman (2009)
item.itunes:author: Eric Dishman
item.description: At TEDMED, Eric Dishman makes a bold argument: The US health care system is like computing circa 1959, tethered to big, unwieldy central systems: hospitals, doctors, nursing homes. As our aging population booms, it's imperative, he says, to create personal, networked, home-based health care for all.
item.itunes:subtitle: Eric Dishman: Take health care off the mainframe

item.title: TEDTalks : Mark Roth: Suspended animation is within our grasp - Mark Roth (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mark Roth
item.description: Mark Roth studies suspended animation: the art of shutting down life processes and then starting them up again. It's wild stuff, but it's not science fiction. Induced by careful use of an otherwise toxic gas, suspended animation can potentially help trauma and heart attack victims survive long enough to be treated.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mark Roth: Suspended animation is within our grasp

item.title: TEDTalks : Dan Barber: How I fell in love with a fish - Dan Barber (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dan Barber
item.description: Chef Dan Barber squares off with a dilemma facing many chefs today: how to keep fish on the menu. With impeccable research and deadpan humor, he chronicles his pursuit of a sustainable fish he could love, and the foodie's honeymoon he's enjoyed since discovering an outrageously delicious fish raised using a revolutionary farming method in Spain.

item.title: TEDTalks : Gary Lauder's new traffic sign: Take Turns - Gary Lauder (2010)
item.itunes:author: Gary Lauder
item.description: Fifty percent of traffic accidents happen at intersections. Gary Lauder shares a brilliant and cheap idea for helping drivers move along smoothly: a new traffic sign that combines the properties of "Stop" and "Yield" -- and asks drivers to be polite.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gary Lauder's new traffic sign: Take Turns
item.itunes:summary: Fifty percent of traffic accidents happen at intersections. Gary Lauder shares a brilliant and cheap idea for helping drivers move along smoothly: a new traffic sign that combines the properties of "Stop" and "Yield" -- and asks drivers to be polite.

item.title: TEDTalks : Tim Berners-Lee: The year open data went worldwide - Tim Berners-Lee (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tim Berners-Lee
item.description: At TED2009, Tim Berners-Lee called for "raw data now" -- for governments, scientists and institutions to make their data openly available on the web. At TED University in 2010, he shows a few of the interesting results when the data gets linked up.
item.itunes:subtitle: Tim Berners-Lee: The year open data went worldwide
item.itunes:summary: At TED2009, Tim Berners-Lee called for "raw data now" -- for governments, scientists and institutions to make their data openly available on the web. At TED University in 2010, he shows a few of the interesting results when the data gets linked up.

item.title: TEDTalks : James Cameron: Before Avatar ... a curious boy - James Cameron (2010)
item.itunes:author: James Cameron
item.description: James Cameron's big-budget (and even bigger-grossing) films create unreal worlds all their own. In this personal talk, he reveals his childhood fascination with the fantastic -- from reading science fiction to deep-sea diving -- and how it ultimately drove the success of his blockbuster hits "Aliens," "The Terminator," "Titanic" and "Avatar."

item.title: TEDTalks : Gary Flake: is Pivot a turning point for web exploration? - Gary Flake (2010)
item.itunes:author: Gary Flake
item.description: Gary Flake demos Pivot, a new way to browse and arrange massive amounts of images and data online. Built on breakthrough Seadragon technology, it enables spectacular zooms in and out of web databases, and the discovery of patterns and links invisible in standard web browsing.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gary Flake: is Pivot a turning point for web exploration?

item.title: TEDTalks : Daniel Kahneman: The riddle of experience vs. memory - Daniel Kahneman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Kahneman
item.description: Using examples from vacations to colonoscopies, Nobel laureate and founder of behavioral economics Daniel Kahneman reveals how our "experiencing selves" and our "remembering selves" perceive happiness differently. This new insight has profound implications for economics, public policy -- and our own self-awareness.

item.title: TEDTalks : Raghava KK: Five lives of an artist - Raghava KK (2010)
item.itunes:author: Raghava KK
item.description: With endearing honesty and vulnerability, Raghava KK tells the colorful tale of how art has taken his life to new places, and how life experiences in turn have driven his multiple reincarnations as an artist -- from cartoonist to painter, media darling to social outcast, and son to father.

item.title: TEDTalks : Temple Grandin: The world needs all kinds of minds - Temple Grandin (2010)
item.itunes:author: Temple Grandin
item.description: Temple Grandin, diagnosed with autism as a child, talks about how her mind works -- sharing her ability to "think in pictures," which helps her solve problems that neurotypical brains might miss. She makes the case that the world needs people on the autism spectrum: visual thinkers, pattern thinkers, verbal thinkers, and all kinds of smart geeky kids.

item.title: TEDTalks : Philip K. Howard: Four ways to fix a broken legal system - Philip K. Howard (2010)
item.itunes:author: Philip K. Howard
item.description: The land of the free has become a legal minefield, says Philip K. Howard -- especially for teachers and doctors, whose work has been paralyzed by fear of suits. What's the answer? A lawyer himself, Howard has four propositions for simplifying US law.

item.title: TEDTalks : Kevin Kelly tells technology's epic story - Kevin Kelly (2009)
item.itunes:author: Kevin Kelly
item.description: In this wide-ranging, thought-provoking talk from TEDxAmsterdam, Kevin Kelly muses on what technology means in our lives -- from its impact at the personal level to its place in the cosmos.

item.itunes:summary: In this wide-ranging, thought-provoking talk from TEDxAmsterdam, Kevin Kelly muses on what technology means in our lives -- from its impact at the personal level to its place in the cosmos.

item.title: TEDTalks : Bill Gates on energy: Innovating to zero! - Bill Gates (2010)
item.itunes:author: Bill Gates
item.description: At TED2010, Bill Gates unveils his vision for the world's energy future, describing the need for "miracles" to avoid planetary catastrophe and explaining why he's backing a dramatically different type of nuclear reactor. The necessary goal? Zero carbon emissions globally by 2050.

item.itunes:author: Peter Eigen
item.description: Some of the world's most baffling social problems, says Peter Eigen, can be traced to systematic, pervasive government corruption, hand-in-glove with global companies. At TEDxBerlin, Eigen describes the thrilling counter-attack led by his organization Transparency International.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jamie Heywood: The big idea my brother inspired - Jamie Heywood (2009)
item.itunes:author: Jamie Heywood
item.description: When Jamie Heywood's brother was diagnosed with ALS, he devoted his life to fighting the disease as well. The Heywood brothers built an ingenious website where people share and track data on their illnesses -- and they discovered that the collective data had enormous power to comfort, explain and predict.

item.title: TEDTalks : Charles Fleischer insists: All things are Moleeds - Charles Fleischer (2005)
item.itunes:author: Charles Fleischer
item.description: In a presentation that can only be described as epic, comedian Charles Fleischer delivers a hysterical send-up of a time-honored TED theme: the map. Geometry, numbers, charts and stamp art also factor in (somehow), as he weaves together a unique theory of everything called "Moleeds."

item.title: TEDTalks : Dan Buettner: How to live to be 100+ - Dan Buettner (2009)
item.itunes:author: Dan Buettner
item.description: To find the path to long life and health, Dan Buettner and team study the world's "Blue Zones," communities whose elders live with vim and vigor to record-setting age. At TEDxTC, he shares the 9 common diet and lifestyle habits that keep them spry past age 100.

item.title: TEDTalks : Nick Veasey: Exposing the invisible - Nick Veasey (2009)
item.itunes:author: Nick Veasey
item.description: Nick Veasey shows outsized X-ray images that reveal the otherworldly inner workings of familiar objects -- from the geometry of a wildflower to the anatomy of a Boeing 747. Producing these photos is dangerous and painstaking, but the reward is a superpower: looking at what the human eye can't see.

item.title: TEDTalks : Steven Cowley: Fusion is energy's future - Steven Cowley (2009)
item.itunes:author: Steven Cowley
item.description: Physicist Steven Cowley is certain that nuclear fusion is the only truly sustainable solution to the fuel crisis. He explains why fusion will work -- and details the projects that he and many others have devoted their lives to, working against the clock to create a new source of energy.

item.itunes:author: Shaffi Mather
item.description: Shaffi Mather explains why he left his first career to become a social entrepreneur, providing life-saving transportation with his company 1298 for Ambulance. Now, he has a new idea and plans to begin a company to fight the booming business of corruption in public service, eliminating it one bribe at a time.

item.title: TEDTalks : Charles Anderson discovers dragonflies that cross oceans - Charles Anderson (2009)
item.itunes:author: Charles Anderson
item.description: While living and working as a marine biologist in Maldives, Charles Anderson noticed sudden explosions of dragonflies at certain times of year. He explains how he carefully tracked the path of a plain, little dragonfly called the globe skimmer, only to discover that it had the longest migratory journey of any insect in the world.

item.title: TEDTalks : Ryan Lobo: Photographing the hidden story - Ryan Lobo (2009)
item.itunes:author: Ryan Lobo
item.description: Ryan Lobo has traveled the world, taking photographs that tell stories of unusual human lives. In this haunting talk, he reframes controversial subjects with empathy, so that we see the pain of a Liberian war criminal, the quiet strength of UN women peacekeepers and the perseverance of Delhi's underappreciated firefighters.

item.description: Sensing the motives and feelings of others is a natural talent for humans. But how do we do it? Here, Rebecca Saxe shares fascinating lab work that uncovers how the brain thinks about other peoples' thoughts -- and judges their actions.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rebecca Saxe: How we read each other's minds
item.itunes:summary: Sensing the motives and feelings of others is a natural talent for humans. But how do we do it? Here, Rebecca Saxe shares fascinating lab work that uncovers how the brain thinks about other peoples' thoughts -- and judges their actions.

item.title: TEDTalks : Lewis Pugh swims the North Pole - Lewis Pugh (2009)
item.itunes:author: Lewis Pugh
item.description: Lewis Pugh talks about his record-breaking swim across the North Pole. He braved the icy waters (in a Speedo) to highlight the melting icecap. Watch for astonishing footage -- and some blunt commentary on the realities of supercold-water swims.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lewis Pugh swims the North Pole
item.itunes:summary: Lewis Pugh talks about his record-breaking swim across the North Pole. He braved the icy waters (in a Speedo) to highlight the melting icecap. Watch for astonishing footage -- and some blunt commentary on the realities of supercold-water swims.

item.title: TEDTalks : James Balog: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss - James Balog (2009)
item.itunes:author: James Balog
item.description: Photographer James Balog shares new image sequences from the Extreme Ice Survey, a network of time-lapse cameras recording glaciers receding at an alarming rate, some of the most vivid evidence yet of climate change.
item.itunes:subtitle: James Balog: Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss
item.itunes:summary: Photographer James Balog shares new image sequences from the Extreme Ice Survey, a network of time-lapse cameras recording glaciers receding at an alarming rate, some of the most vivid evidence yet of climate change.

item.title: TEDTalks : Geoff Mulgan: Post-crash, investing in a better world - Geoff Mulgan (2009)
item.itunes:author: Geoff Mulgan
item.description: As we reboot the world's economy, Geoff Mulgan poses a question: Instead of sending bailout money to doomed old industries, why not use stimulus funds to bootstrap some new, socially responsible companies -- and make the world a little bit better?
item.itunes:subtitle: Geoff Mulgan: Post-crash, investing in a better world
item.itunes:summary: As we reboot the world's economy, Geoff Mulgan poses a question: Instead of sending bailout money to doomed old industries, why not use stimulus funds to bootstrap some new, socially responsible companies -- and make the world a little bit better?

item.title: TEDTalks : Josh Silver demos adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses - Joshua Silver (2009)
item.itunes:author: Joshua Silver
item.description: Josh Silver delivers his brilliantly simple solution for correcting vision at the lowest cost possible -- adjustable, liquid-filled lenses. At TEDGlobal 2009, he demos his affordable eyeglasses and reveals his global plan to distribute them to a billion people in need by 2020.
item.itunes:subtitle: Josh Silver demos adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses
item.itunes:summary: Josh Silver delivers his brilliantly simple solution for correcting vision at the lowest cost possible -- adjustable, liquid-filled lenses. At TEDGlobal 2009, he demos his affordable eyeglasses and reveals his global plan to distribute them to a billion people in need by 2020.

item.title: TEDTalks : Cary Fowler: One seed at a time, protecting the future of food - Cary Fowler (2009)
item.itunes:author: Cary Fowler
item.description: The varieties of wheat, corn and rice we grow today may not thrive in a future threatened by climate change. Cary Fowler takes us inside a vast global seed bank, buried within a frozen mountain in Norway, that stores a diverse group of food-crop for whatever tomorrow may bring.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cary Fowler: One seed at a time, protecting the future of food
item.itunes:summary: The varieties of wheat, corn and rice we grow today may not thrive in a future threatened by climate change. Cary Fowler takes us inside a vast global seed bank, buried within a frozen mountain in Norway, that stores a diverse group of food-crop for whatever tomorrow may bring.

item.title: TEDTalks : Natasha Tsakos' multimedia theatrical adventure - Natasha Tsakos (2009)
item.itunes:author: Natasha Tsakos
item.description: Natasha Tsakos presents part of her one-woman, multimedia show, "Upwake." As the character Zero, she blends dream and reality with an inventive virtual world projected around her in 3D animation and electric sound.
item.itunes:subtitle: Natasha Tsakos' multimedia theatrical adventure
item.itunes:summary: Natasha Tsakos presents part of her one-woman, multimedia show, "Upwake." As the character Zero, she blends dream and reality with an inventive virtual world projected around her in 3D animation and electric sound.

item.title: TEDTalks : Hans Rosling: Let my dataset change your mindset - Hans Rosling (2009)
item.itunes:author: Hans Rosling
item.description: Talking at the US State Department this summer, Hans Rosling uses his fascinating data-bubble software to burst myths about the developing world. Look for new analysis on China and the post-bailout world, mixed with classic data shows.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hans Rosling: Let my dataset change your mindset
item.itunes:summary: Talking at the US State Department this summer, Hans Rosling uses his fascinating data-bubble software to burst myths about the developing world. Look for new analysis on China and the post-bailout world, mixed with classic data shows.

item.title: TEDTalks : Eric Giler demos wireless electricity - Eric Giler (2009)
item.itunes:author: Eric Giler
item.description: Eric Giler wants to untangle our wired lives with cable-free electric power. Here, he covers what this sci-fi tech offers, and demos MIT's breakthrough version, WiTricity -- a near-to-market invention that may soon recharge your cell phone, car, pacemaker.
item.itunes:subtitle: Eric Giler demos wireless electricity

item.title: TEDTalks : Dan Pink on the surprising science of motivation - Dan Pink (2009)
item.itunes:author: Dan Pink
item.description: Career analyst Dan Pink examines the puzzle of motivation, starting with a fact that social scientists know but most managers don't: Traditional rewards aren't always as effective as we think. Listen for illuminating stories -- and maybe, a way forward.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan Pink on the surprising science of motivation
item.itunes:summary: Career analyst Dan Pink examines the puzzle of motivation, starting with a fact that social scientists know but most managers don't: Traditional rewards aren't always as effective as we think. Listen for illuminating stories -- and maybe, a way forward.

item.title: TEDTalks : Emmanuel Jal: The music of a war child - Emmanuel Jal (2009)
item.itunes:author: Emmanuel Jal
item.description: For five years, young Emmanuel Jal fought as a child soldier in the Sudan. Rescued by an aid worker, he's become an international hip-hop star and an activist for kids in war zones. In words and lyrics, he tells the story of his amazing life.
item.itunes:subtitle: Emmanuel Jal: The music of a war child

item.title: TEDTalks : Michael Pritchard's water filter turns filthy water drinkable - Michael Pritchard (2009)
item.itunes:author: Michael Pritchard
item.description: Too much of the world lacks access to clean drinking water. Engineer Michael Pritchard did something about it -- inventing the portable Lifesaver filter, which can make the most revolting water drinkable in seconds. An amazing demo from TEDGlobal 2009.
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael Pritchard's water filter turns filthy water drinkable
item.itunes:summary: Too much of the world lacks access to clean drinking water. Engineer Michael Pritchard did something about it -- inventing the portable Lifesaver filter, which can make the most revolting water drinkable in seconds. An amazing demo from TEDGlobal 2009.

item.title: TEDTalks : Willard Wigan: Hold your breath for micro-sculpture - Willard Wigan (2009)
item.itunes:author: Willard Wigan
item.description: Willard Wigan tells the story of how a difficult and lonely childhood drove him to discover his unique ability -- to create art so tiny that it can't be seen with the naked eye. His slideshow of figures, as seen through a microscope, can only be described as mind-boggling.
item.itunes:subtitle: Willard Wigan: Hold your breath for micro-sculpture

item.title: TEDTalks : Paul Romer's radical idea: Charter cities - Paul Romer (2009)
item.itunes:author: Paul Romer
item.description: How can a struggling country break out of poverty if it's trapped in a system of bad rules? Economist Paul Romer unveils a bold idea: "charter cities," city-scale administrative zones governed by a coalition of nations. (Could Guantánamo Bay become the next Hong Kong?)
item.itunes:subtitle: Paul Romer's radical idea: Charter cities
item.itunes:summary: How can a struggling country break out of poverty if it's trapped in a system of bad rules? Economist Paul Romer unveils a bold idea: "charter cities," city-scale administrative zones governed by a coalition of nations. (Could Guantánamo Bay become the next Hong Kong?)

item.title: TEDTalks : Elaine Morgan says we evolved from aquatic apes - Elaine Morgan (2009)
item.itunes:author: Elaine Morgan
item.description: Elaine Morgan is a tenacious proponent of the aquatic ape hypothesis: the idea that humans evolved from primate ancestors who dwelt in watery habitats. Hear her spirited defense of the idea -- and her theory on why mainstream science doesn't take it seriously.
item.itunes:subtitle: Elaine Morgan says we evolved from aquatic apes
item.itunes:summary: Elaine Morgan is a tenacious proponent of the aquatic ape hypothesis: the idea that humans evolved from primate ancestors who dwelt in watery habitats. Hear her spirited defense of the idea -- and her theory on why mainstream science doesn't take it seriously.

item.title: TEDTalks : Alain de Botton: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success - Alain de Botton (2009)
item.itunes:author: Alain de Botton
item.description: Alain de Botton examines our ideas of success and failure -- and questions the assumptions underlying these two judgments. Is success always earned? Is failure? He makes an eloquent, witty case to move beyond snobbery to find true pleasure in our work.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alain de Botton: A kinder, gentler philosophy of success
item.itunes:summary: Alain de Botton examines our ideas of success and failure -- and questions the assumptions underlying these two judgments. Is success always earned? Is failure? He makes an eloquent, witty case to move beyond snobbery to find true pleasure in our work.

item.title: TEDTalks : Nina Jablonski breaks the illusion of skin color - Nina Jablonski (2009)
item.itunes:author: Nina Jablonski
item.description: Nina Jablonski says that differing skin colors are simply our bodies' adaptation to varied climates and levels of UV exposure. Charles Darwin disagreed with this theory, but she explains, that's because he did not have access to NASA.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nina Jablonski breaks the illusion of skin color
item.itunes:summary: Nina Jablonski says that differing skin colors are simply our bodies' adaptation to varied climates and levels of UV exposure. Charles Darwin disagreed with this theory, but she explains, that's because he did not have access to NASA.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jim Fallon: Exploring the mind of a killer - Jim Fallon (2009)
item.itunes:author: Jim Fallon
item.description: Psychopathic killers are the basis for some must-watch TV, but what really makes them tick? Neuroscientist Jim Fallon talks about brain scans and genetic analysis that may uncover the rotten wiring in the nature (and nurture) of murderers. In a too-strange-for-fiction twist, he shares a fascinating family history that makes his work chillingly personal.

item.title: TEDTalks : Daniel Kraft invents a better way to harvest bone marrow - Daniel Kraft (2009)
item.itunes:author: Daniel Kraft
item.description: Daniel Kraft demos his Marrow Miner -- a new device that quickly harvests life-saving bone marrow with minimal pain to the donor. He emphasizes that the adult stem cells found in bone marrow can be used to treat many terminal conditions, from Parkinson's to heart disease.
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel Kraft invents a better way to harvest bone marrow

item.itunes:author: Olafur Eliasson
item.description: In the spectacular large-scale projects he's famous for (such as "Waterfalls" in New York harbor), Olafur Eliasson creates art from a palette of space, distance, color and light. This idea-packed talk begins with an experiment in the nature of perception.

item.title: TEDTalks : Kary Mullis' next-gen cure for killer infections - Kary Mullis (2009)
item.itunes:author: Kary Mullis
item.description: Drug-resistant bacteria kills, even in top hospitals. But now tough infections like staph and anthrax may be in for a surprise. Nobel-winning chemist Kary Mullis, who watched a friend die when powerful antibiotics failed, unveils a radical new cure that shows extraordinary promise.

item.itunes:author: Sophal Ear

item.itunes:author: Eames Demetrios

item.title: TEDTalks : Arthur Benjamin's formula for changing math education - Arthur Benjamin (2009)
item.itunes:author: Arthur Benjamin
item.description: Someone always asks the math teacher, "Am I going to use calculus in real life?" And for most of us, says Arthur Benjamin, the answer is no. He offers a bold proposal on how to make math education relevant in the digital age.

item.itunes:author: Ray Zahab

item.itunes:author: Katherine Fulton
item.description: In this uplifting talk, Katherine Fulton sketches the new future of philanthropy -- one where collaboration and innovation allow regular people to do big things, even when money is scarce. item.title: TEDTalks : Paul Collier's new rules for rebuilding a broken nation - Paul Collier (2009)
item.itunes:author: Paul Collier
item.description: Long conflict can wreck a country, leaving behind poverty and chaos. But what's the right way to help war-torn countries rebuild? At TED@State, Paul Collier explains the problems with current post-conflict aid plans, and suggests 3 ideas for a better approach.

item.title: TEDTalks : Philip Zimbardo prescribes a healthy take on time - Philip Zimbardo (2009)
item.itunes:author: Philip Zimbardo
item.description: Psychologist Philip Zimbardo says happiness and success are rooted in a trait most of us disregard: the way we orient toward the past, present and future. He suggests we calibrate our outlook on time as a first step to improving our lives.

item.itunes:author: Catherine Mohr
item.description: Surgeon and inventor Catherine Mohr tours the history of surgery (and its pre-painkiller, pre-antiseptic past), then demos some of the newest tools for surgery through tiny incisions, performed using nimble robot hands. Fascinating -- but not for the squeamish.

item.title: TEDTalks : Clay Shirky: How social media can make history - Clay Shirky (2009)
item.itunes:author: Clay Shirky
item.description: While news from Iran streams to the world, Clay Shirky shows how Facebook, Twitter and TXTs help citizens in repressive regimes to report on real news, bypassing censors (however briefly). The end of top-down control of news is changing the nature of politics.

item.title: TEDTalks : Jane Poynter: Life in Biosphere 2 - Jane Poynter (2009)
item.itunes:author: Jane Poynter

item.itunes:summary: Jay Walker explains why two billion people around the world are trying to learn English. He shares photos and spine-tingling audio of Chinese students rehearsing English -- "the world's second language" -- by the thousands.

item.itunes:summary: Yves Behar and Forrest North unveil Mission One, a sleek, powerful electric motorcycle. They share slides from distant (yet similar) childhoods that show how collaboration kick-started their friendship -- and shared dreams.

item.title: TEDTalks : Carolyn Porco: Could a Saturn moon harbor life? - Carolyn Porco (2009)
item.itunes:author: Carolyn Porco
item.description: Carolyn Porco shares exciting new findings from the Cassini spacecraft's recent sweep of one of Saturn's moons, Enceladus. Samples gathered from the moon's icy geysers hint that an ocean under its surface could harbor life.

item.itunes:author: Mary Roach

item.itunes:author: Ray Anderson

item.itunes:author: Alex Tabarrok

item.itunes:author: Sirena Huang
item.description: Violinist Sirena Huang gives a technically brilliant and emotionally nuanced performance. In a charming interlude, the 11-year-old praises the timeless design of her instrument.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sirena Huang dazzles on violin

item.title: TEDTalks : Magical improv from 14-year-old pianist - Jennifer Lin (2004)
item.itunes:author: Jennifer Lin
item.description: Pianist and composer Jennifer Lin gives a magical performance, talks about the process of creativity and improvises a moving solo piece based on a random sequence of notes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jennifer Lin improvs piano magic

item.title: TEDTalks : The vision behind One Laptop Per Child - Nicholas Negroponte (2006)
item.itunes:author: Nicholas Negroponte
item.description: Nicholas Negroponte, founder of the MIT Media Laboratory, describes how the One Laptop Per Child project will build and distribute the "$100 laptop."
item.itunes:subtitle: Nicholas Negroponte on One Laptop per Child

item.title: TEDTalks : TED Prize wish: Open-source architecture to house the world - Cameron Sinclair (2006)
item.itunes:author: Cameron Sinclair
item.description: Accepting his 2006 TED Prize, Cameron Sinclair demonstrates how passionate designers and architects can respond to world housing crises. He unveils his TED Prize wish for a network to improve global living standards through collaborative design.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cameron Sinclair on open-source architecture
item.itunes:summary: Accepting his 2006 TED Prize, Cameron Sinclair demonstrates how passionate designers and architects can respond to world housing crises. He unveils his TED Prize wish for a network to improve global living standards through collaborative design.

item.title: TEDTalks : TED Prize wish: Unite the world on Pangea Day, a global day of film - Jehane Noujaim (2006)
item.itunes:author: Jehane Noujaim
item.description: In this hopeful talk, Jehane Noujaim unveils her 2006 TED Prize wish: to bring the world together for one day a year through the power of film.

item.itunes:summary: In this hopeful talk, Jehane Noujaim unveils her 2006 TED Prize wish: to bring the world together for one day a year through the power of film.

item.title: TEDTalks : TED Prize wish: Help stop the next pandemic - Larry Brilliant (2006)
item.itunes:author: Larry Brilliant
item.description: Accepting the 2006 TED Prize, Dr. Larry Brilliant talks about how smallpox was eradicated from the planet, and calls for a new global system that can identify and contain pandemics before they spread.

item.itunes:summary: Accepting the 2006 TED Prize, Dr. Larry Brilliant talks about how smallpox was eradicated from the planet, and calls for a new global system that can identify and contain pandemics before they spread.

item.title: TEDTalks : Living a life of purpose - Rick Warren (2006)
item.itunes:author: Rick Warren
item.description: Pastor Rick Warren, author of The Purpose-Driven Life, reflects on his own crisis of purpose in the wake of his book's wild success. He explains his belief that God's intention is for each of us to use our talents and influence to do good.

item.title: TEDTalks : "Letting Go of God" (an excerpt) - Julia Sweeney (2006)
item.itunes:author: Julia Sweeney
item.description: Julia Sweeney (God Said, "Ha!") performs the first 15 minutes of her 2006 solo show Letting Go of God. When two young Mormon missionaries knock on her door one day, it touches off a quest to completely rethink her own beliefs.

item.title: TEDTalks : 15 ways to avert a climate crisis - Al Gore (2006)
item.itunes:author: Al Gore
item.description: With the same humor and humanity he exuded in An Inconvenient Truth, Al Gore spells out 15 ways that individuals can address climate change immediately, from buying a hybrid to inventing a new, hotter "brand name" for global warming.

item.title: TEDTalks : When it comes to tech, simplicity sells - David Pogue (2006)
item.itunes:author: David Pogue

item.title: TEDTalks : Greening the ghetto - Majora Carter (2006)
item.itunes:author: Majora Carter
item.description: In an emotionally charged talk, MacArthur-winning activist Majora Carter details her fight for environmental justice in the South Bronx -- and shows how minority neighborhoods suffer most from flawed urban policy.

item.title: TEDTalks : Do schools kill creativity? - Ken Robinson (2006)
item.itunes:author: Ken Robinson
item.description: Sir Ken Robinson makes an entertaining and profoundly moving case for creating an education system that nurtures (rather than undermines) creativity.
